'Shropshire' ( or ; alternatively 'Salop'; Blandings:
English Counties â broken link abbreviated,
in print only, 'Shrops' [http://acronyms.thefreedictionary.com/SHROPS
SHROPS â What does SHROPS stand for? Acronyms and abbreviations by the Free
Online Dictionary]. Acronyms.thefreedictionary.com. Retrieved on 25 August
2011. ) is a county in the West Midlands region of England. It borders
Wales to the west (Powys to the west, and Wrexham to the north west), Cheshire
to the north, Staffordshire to the east, Worcestershire to the south-east and
Herefordshire to the south. A unitary authority (Shropshire Council) was
created on 1 April 2009, taking over from the previous county council and 5
district councils, and covers most of the county. The borough of Telford and
Wrekin has been a separate unitary authority since 1998 but continues to be
included in the ceremonial county.

The county's population and economy is centred on five towns: the county town of
Shrewsbury, which is culturally and historically important and is located in the
centre of the county; [http://www.shropshiretourism.co.uk/shrewsbury/
Shrewsbury â Tourist Information & Accommodation] for Shrewsbury,
Shropshire. Telford, a new town in the east which was constructed around a
number of older towns, most notably Wellington, Dawley and Madeley, which is
today the most populous; [http://www.wrexhamandshropshire.co.uk/telford.php
Wrexham & Shropshire :: Telford]. and Oswestry in the north-west,
Bridgnorth just to the south of Telford, and Ludlow in the south. The county has
many further market towns, including Whitchurch in the north, Newport just to
the north-east of Telford, and Market Drayton in the north-east of the county.

The Ironbridge Gorge area is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, covering Ironbridge,
Coalbrookdale and a part of Madeley. [http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/371
Ironbridge Page on UNESCO World Heritage website]. Whc.unesco.org (6 March
2007). Retrieved on 25 August 2011. There are, additionally, other notable
historic industrial sites located around the county, such as at Shrewsbury,
Broseley, Snailbeach and Highley as well as the Shropshire Union
Canal. [http://www.bbc.co.uk/shropshire/features/2002/09/iarecordings.shtml
BBC â Shropshire â Features â Industrial Archeology].

The Shropshire Hills Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty covers about a quarter
of the county, mainly in the south. [http://www.shropshirehillsaonb.co.uk/
Shropshire Hills AONB]. Shropshire Hills AONB. Retrieved on 25 August
2011. Shropshire is one of England's most rural and sparsely populated
counties, with the population density of the Shropshire Council area being just
91/km 2 (337/sq mi). [http://www.shropsh-
ire.gov.uk/factsfigures.nsf/viewAttachments/SSER-7U2EJQ/$file/m03-005-key-facts-
about-Shropshire.pdf ] The Wrekin is one of the most famous natural
landmarks in the county, [http://www.shropshirerocks.org/shropshiregeologic-
altrail/thewrekinandercall shropshirerocks.org: The Wrekin & The Ercall]
though the highest hills are the Clee Hills, [http://www.shropshirerocks.or-
g/shropshiregeologicaltrail/browncleehill shropshirerocks.org: Brown Clee
Hill] Stiperstones [http://www.shropshirerocks.org/shropshiregeologic-
altrail/thestiperstones shropshirerocks.org: The Stiperstones] and the
Long
Mynd. [http://www.shropshirerocks.org/shropshiregeologicaltrail/thelongmynd
shropshirerocks.org: The Long Mynd] Wenlock Edge is another significant
geographical and geological landmark. [http://www.shropshirerocks.org/shrop-
shiregeologicaltrail/wenlockedge/ shropshirerocks.org: Wenlock Edge] In
the low-lying northwest of the county (and overlapping the border with Wales) is
the Fenn's, Whixall and Bettisfield Mosses National Nature Reserve, one of the
most important and best preserved bogs in Britain. The River Severn, Great
Britain's longest river, runs through the county, exiting into Worcestershire
via the Severn Valley. Shropshire is landlocked, and with an area of , is England's largest inland county. [http://www.-
shropshire.gov.uk/shropshirecouncil.nsf/open/8BD3AF394D3AF171802574CC00439CF8
Shropshire Council]. Shropshire.gov.uk (15 July 2011). Retrieved on 25 August
2011.

The county flower is the round-leaved sundew. [http://www.plantlife.org.uk/uk/plantlife-discovering-plants-
county-flowers-england-shropshire.htm website]. Plantlife.org.uk. Retrieved on
25 August 2011. For Eurostat purposes, the county (less the unitary
district of Telford and Wrekin) is a NUTS 3 region (code UKG22). The two
Shropshire unitary areas (covering all of the ceremonial county), together with
the authorities covering the ceremonial county of Staffordshire, comprise the
"Shropshire and Staffordshire" NUTS 2 region.
categories: Local government districts of the West Midlands (region)
NUTS 3 statistical regions of the United Kingdom
